articles.headline: A Company’s Stand for Gay Marriage, and Its Cost
articles.snippet: Replacements Limited, of North Carolina, lost customers and got a lot of hate mail when it and its founder urged voters to reject a gay marriage ban.
articles.abstract: Replacements Limited, of North Carolina, lost customers and got a lot of hate mail when it and its founder urged voters to reject a gay marriage ban.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the months leading up to North Carolina’s vote this month to ban gay marriage, most of the state’s business leaders were conspicuously silent. While some executives spoke out against it as individuals, not one Fortune 500 company based in North Carolina, including Bank of America, Duke Energy, VF Corporation and Lowe’s, opposed it.

articles.headline: The Challenge of Starting an Airline
articles.snippet: With the big carriers cutting routes and raising fares, this would seem like an ideal time for a new airline to take them on. But it’s not an easy task.
articles.abstract: With the big carriers cutting routes and raising fares, this would seem like an ideal time for a new airline to take them on. But it’s not an easy task.
articles.lead_paragraph: Where are the start-up airlines?

articles.headline: Giant Lender in Spain Asks for Billions to Fend Off Collapse
articles.snippet: Spain is trying to avert a failure of Bankia, its biggest mortgage lender, which could threaten the Spanish banking industry and reverberate through Europe and beyond.
articles.abstract: Spain is trying to avert a failure of Bankia, its biggest mortgage lender, which could threaten the Spanish banking industry and reverberate through Europe and beyond.
articles.lead_paragraph: MADRID — Spain’s banking crisis worsened Friday as the board of Bankia, the country’s biggest mortgage lender, warned that it would need an additional 19 billion euros ($23.88 billion), far beyond what the government estimated when it seized the bank and its portfolio of delinquent real estate loans earlier this month.

articles.headline: Hope and Frustration in New U.S. Effort to Help Homeowners
articles.snippet: Despite some problems with lenders, a new version of the HARP federal refinancing program offers less restrictive rules — but the success of the program remains to be seen.
articles.abstract: Despite some problems with lenders, a new version of the HARP federal refinancing program offers less restrictive rules — but the success of the program remains to be seen.
articles.lead_paragraph: As mortgage rates have hit one record low after another, millions of homeowners have been forced to watch, longingly, from the sidelines. They haven’t had the option of refinancing because sliding home values pushed their mortgages underwater, meaning they owe more than their homes are worth. The banks would just not work with them.

articles.headline: In Vatican Whodunit, a Punch Line of a Suspect
articles.snippet: An on-again, off-again scandal burst into the open with the arrest of Pope Benedict XVI’s butler, suspected of leaking private letters addressed to the pope.
articles.abstract: An on-again, off-again scandal burst into the open with the arrest of Pope Benedict XVI’s butler, suspected of leaking private letters addressed to the pope.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROME — A mysterious source named Maria. A room furnished with a single chair where sensitive Vatican documents are turned over to an investigative journalist at regular meetings. The arrest of the pope’s butler. Perhaps the greatest breach in centuries in the wall of secrecy that surrounds the Vatican.

articles.headline: Bank Regulators Under Scrutiny in JPMorgan Loss
articles.snippet: Fallout from JPMorgan Chase’s bad bets is revealing lapses in the policing of the office that disclosed a multibillion trading loss.
articles.abstract: Fallout from JPMorgan Chase’s bad bets is revealing lapses in the policing of the office that disclosed a multibillion trading loss.
articles.lead_paragraph: Scores of federal regulators are stationed inside JPMorgan Chase’s Manhattan headquarters, but none of them were assigned to the powerful unit that recently disclosed a multibillion trading loss.
articles.byline: By Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Drug for Adults Is Popular as Children’s Remedy
articles.snippet: Parents are questioning the long-term effects of the often-used laxative, Miralax, which has become a staple in many American households since it was first introduced 13 years ago.
articles.abstract: Parents are questioning the long-term effects of the often-used laxative, Miralax, which has become a staple in many American households since it was first introduced 13 years ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since it was first introduced 13 years ago, a drug called Miralax — an odorless, tasteless laxative that can be easily diluted in orange juice or water — has become a staple in many American households.

articles.headline: Presidential Panel Urges More Flexible Use of Spectrum
articles.snippet: A shift in computer technologies would relieve radio spectrum congestion caused by the popularity of smartphones, the authors of a report said.
articles.abstract: A shift in computer technologies would relieve radio spectrum congestion caused by the popularity of smartphones, the authors of a report said.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — A just-completed report from a presidential advisory committee urges President Obama to adopt new computer technologies to make better use of a huge swath of the radio spectrum now controlled by federal agencies.

articles.headline: Dozens of Children Die in Brutal Attack on Syrian Town
articles.snippet: At least 32 children were among more than 90 people killed in Houla, Syria, top United Nations officials said, accusing Syria’s government of “indiscriminate” shelling.
articles.abstract: At least 32 children were among more than 90 people killed in Houla, Syria, top United Nations officials said, accusing Syria’s government of “indiscriminate” shelling.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — More than 90 people, including at least 32 children under the age of 10, were killed in a central Syrian village, top United Nations officials said Saturday, accusing the government of perpetrating the “indiscriminate” shelling of civilian neighborhoods.
articles.byline: By Neil MacFarquhar and Hwaida Saad

articles.headline: With Personal Data in Hand, Thieves File Early and Often
articles.snippet: Criminals filing false tax returns with made-up incomes have received hundreds of millions of dollars in refunds, law enforcement officials say.
articles.abstract: Criminals filing false tax returns with made-up incomes have received hundreds of millions of dollars in refunds, law enforcement officials say.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Besieged by identity theft, Florida now faces a fast-spreading form of fraud so simple and lucrative that some violent criminals have traded their guns for laptops. And the target is the United States Treasury.

articles.headline: The Hunch, the Pounce and the Kill
articles.snippet: JPMorgan Chase lost big because of outsize trades, but not before Boaz Weinstein, a hedge fund manager, seized a rich opportunity, winning in a high-risk game of nerves.
articles.abstract: JPMorgan Chase lost big because of outsize trades, but not before Boaz Weinstein, a hedge fund manager, seized a rich opportunity, winning in a high-risk game of nerves.
articles.lead_paragraph: BOAZ WEINSTEIN didn’t know it, but he had just hooked the London Whale.

articles.headline: Quick Getaways, at the Divorce Hotel
articles.snippet: The Dutch entrepreneur behind Divorce Hotel, a weekend program for couples looking to end their marriages quickly, wants to introduce the concept to the United States.
articles.abstract: The Dutch entrepreneur behind Divorce Hotel, a weekend program for couples looking to end their marriages quickly, wants to introduce the concept to the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE American marriage, it seems, is on the rocks. The common line — true or not — is that half of all marriages in this country end in divorce.

articles.headline: A Director With Irons in So Many Fires
articles.snippet: The woes are multiplying for James W. Breyer, a venture capitalist who is on the board of four companies with high-profile problems: Facebook, Dell, News Corporation and Wal-Mart.
articles.abstract: The woes are multiplying for James W. Breyer, a venture capitalist who is on the board of four companies with high-profile problems: Facebook, Dell, News Corporation and Wal-Mart.
articles.lead_paragraph: NOT long ago, serving on the board of Facebook must have seemed awfully glamorous.

articles.headline: In Rarefied Sport, a View of the Romneys’ World
articles.snippet: A lawsuit, since settled, offers a glimpse into dressage, the chosen sport of Mitt Romney’s wife, and into the elite world of expensive horses.
articles.abstract: A lawsuit, since settled, offers a glimpse into dressage, the chosen sport of Mitt Romney’s wife, and into the elite world of expensive horses.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Ann Romney immersed herself in the elite world of riding over the last dozen years, she relied on Jan Ebeling as a trusted tutor and horse scout. In her, he found a deep-pocketed patron.

articles.headline: U.S. Hopes Assad Can Be Eased Out With Russia’s Aid
articles.snippet: In a new effort to halt bloodshed in Syria, President Obama will push for the departure of President Bashar al-Assad under a proposal modeled on the transition in Yemen.
articles.abstract: In a new effort to halt bloodshed in Syria, President Obama will push for the departure of President Bashar al-Assad under a proposal modeled on the transition in Yemen.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a new effort to halt more than a year of bloodshed in Syria, President Obama will push for the departure of President Bashar al-Assad under a proposal modeled on the transition in another strife-torn Arab country, Yemen.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper and Mark Landler

articles.headline: U.S. Efforts Fail to Curtail Trade in Afghan Opium
articles.snippet: Some officials privately concede that there is little chance for large-scale success of the anti-opium effort in Afghanistan before the end of the NATO military mission in 2014.
articles.abstract: Some officials privately concede that there is little chance for large-scale success of the anti-opium effort in Afghanistan before the end of the NATO military mission in 2014.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — For years, American officials have struggled to curb Afghanistan’s opium industry, rewriting strategy every few seasons and pouring in more than $6 billion over the past decade to combat the poppies that help finance the insurgency and fuel corruption.
articles.byline: By Alissa J. Rubin and Matthew Rosenberg

articles.headline: U.N. Security Council Issues Condemnation of Syria Attack
articles.snippet: The United Nations action over a massacre this weekend of at least 108 villagers was the strongest yet allowed by Russia, which has blocked criticism of Syria’s president.
articles.abstract: The United Nations action over a massacre this weekend of at least 108 villagers was the strongest yet allowed by Russia, which has blocked criticism of Syria’s president.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The United Nations Security Council on Sunday unanimously condemned the Syrian government for its role in the massacre of at least 108 villagers, with new details emerging from international observers that appeared to prompt rare Russian cooperation in criticizing its ally in Damascus.

articles.headline: For Tech Start-Ups, New York Has Increasing Allure
articles.snippet: New York may not be overtaking the Bay Area as a technology hub, but it is becoming enough of an alternative that a few West Coast-born startups are moving east.
articles.abstract: New York may not be overtaking the Bay Area as a technology hub, but it is becoming enough of an alternative that a few West Coast-born startups are moving east.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Doug Imbruce wanted to start an interactive video company in 2009, he had no luck finding investors in New York. So he moved to Silicon Valley — where venture capitalists were receptive to his pitch — and founded Qwiki.

articles.headline: As Euro Bond Wins Supporters, Details Remain Vague
articles.snippet: Europeans are deeply divided over the question of whether euro zone countries should create common bonds to reduce borrowing costs for members that have trouble getting affordable credit.
articles.abstract: Europeans are deeply divided over the question of whether euro zone countries should create common bonds to reduce borrowing costs for members that have trouble getting affordable credit.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — To euro zone countries in need, euro bonds would be a noble expression of European solidarity and a crucial instrument for preserving the common currency.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing and Paul Geitner

articles.headline: Forecasting Hollywood Academy’s Succession
articles.snippet: Because of term limits, Tom Sherak, president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, is leaving a post that has emerged as one of the few bully pulpits in the film business.
articles.abstract: Because of term limits, Tom Sherak, president of the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, is leaving a post that has emerged as one of the few bully pulpits in the film business.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — No white smoke rises when the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences elects its new president.

articles.headline: A Doomed Romance With a New Orleans Newspaper
articles.snippet: In a city where not much of anything works, The Times-Picayune does, and nothing got print romanticists more dewy-eyed than the announcement of its reduced schedule.
articles.abstract: In a city where not much of anything works, The Times-Picayune does, and nothing got print romanticists more dewy-eyed than the announcement of its reduced schedule.
articles.lead_paragraph: If it keeps on raining, levee’s going to break — “When the Levee Breaks,” Led Zeppelin

articles.headline: West Point Is Divided on a War Doctrine’s Fate
articles.snippet: Faculty at the United States Military Academy are debating what a counterinsurgency strategy achieved in Iraq and Afghanistan and whether the doctrine has a future.
articles.abstract: Faculty at the United States Military Academy are debating what a counterinsurgency strategy achieved in Iraq and Afghanistan and whether the doctrine has a future.
articles.lead_paragraph: WEST POINT, N.Y. — For two centuries, the United States Military Academy has produced generals for America’s wars, among them Ulysses S. Grant, Robert E. Lee, George S. Patton and David H. Petraeus. It is where President George W. Bush delivered what became known as his pre-emption speech, which sought to justify the invasion of Iraq, and where President Obama told the nation he was sending an additional 30,000 American troops to Afghanistan.

articles.headline: Obama Finds Campaigning Rules Clock
articles.snippet: Running like a challenger, President Obama is increasingly consumed by a campaign that is shaping his schedule, his message and many of his decisions.
articles.abstract: Running like a challenger, President Obama is increasingly consumed by a campaign that is shaping his schedule, his message and many of his decisions.
articles.lead_paragraph: REDWOOD CITY, Calif. — By the time President Obama took the stage at the Fox Theater here, he was in the 18th hour of a 19-hour day. His tie was still knotted to the top as he launched into his stump speech, attacking his opponent’s record and defending his own. “I still believe in you,” he said, “and I hope you still believe in me.”

articles.headline: Spain’s Borrowing Costs Rise as Bank Woes Deepen
articles.snippet: Spain’s borrowing costs neared record highs amid concerns over the plan to bail out Bankia.
articles.abstract: Spain’s borrowing costs neared record highs amid concerns over the plan to bail out Bankia.
articles.lead_paragraph: MADRID — Spain’s borrowing costs approached record highs on Monday as investors fretted over how the government would find additional money to bail out Bankia, the country’s largest mortgage lender, and other troubled banks.
